name: More Fractured Presidents Quiz | Fractured Words | 15 Questions

questions.explanation:
Thomas Jefferson.

	1801-1809. Our third President. A great patriot, thinker, and writer, but perhaps he should have tried to free the slaves if he believed so strongly in equal rights.

John Adams.

	1797-1801. Our second Prez. His son, John Quincy Adams, was a President, too.

questions.correct: William Howard Taft & William H. Taft & William Taft & William H Taft
questions.explanation:
William Howard Taft & William H. Taft & William Taft & William H Taft

	1909-1913. Later he became Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.

Herbert Hoover.

	1929-1933. Homeless people's tacked-together shanty towns were dubbed Hoovervilles, since many blamed Hoover for the Crash of '29 and the Great Depression that followed.

questions.correct: John Fitzgerald Kennedy & JFK & John F. Kennedy & John Kennedy & John F Kennedy
questions.explanation:
John Fitzgerald Kennedy & JFK & John F. Kennedy & John Kennedy & John F Kennedy

	1961-1963. Young, handsome, rich, smart, and married to the beautiful Jackie, JFK was one of our most charismatic Presidents. He was assassinated in Dallas on November 22, 1963. If you're in your 40s or older, you probably remember where you were when you heard the news. Lyndon B. Johnson, his VP, took over as President that evening. Tragically, his brother Robert was also assassinated while running for President, and his handsome son died in a plane crash.

questions.explanation:
Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

	1933-1945. FDR served longer as President than any other person. He was elected four times. Roosevelt's New Deal legislation helped to boost the U.S. out of the Depression. He led the nation through World War II, but died in office when the War was almost over. VP Harry S. Truman took over. (Now Presidents can serve only two four-year terms. A player points out that if a President dies in office and the VP takes over, the new Prez is allowed to run twice more IF he or she does not serve more than two years of the previous President's term--so a President could conceivably spend up to 10 years in office.)(Editor's note: Only the full name is acceptable as that is what the fracture represents.)

Ronald Reagan.

	1981-1989. The Great Communicator. Not my favorite President, but I'm sad that he developed Alzheimer's.

Andrew Johnson.

	1865-1869. President during Reconstruction. Too bad Lincoln wasn't.

William McKinley.

	1897-1901. There were a lot of Presidents named William, weren't there?

James Knox Polk & James K. Polk & James Polk&james k polk

	1845-1849.

George Herbert Walker Bush.

	1989-1993. Dad to Dubya. Credited with ending the Cold War. Led the U.S. through the Gulf War.

George Washington.

	Our first Prez: 1789-1797. The Father of Our Country, the cannot-tell-a-lie guy. Led the Patriots through the Revolutionary War. Had wooden false teeth, they say.

James Madison.

	1809-1817. Husband to Dolley. If you want your boy to be President, name him George, James, or William--John might work, too, or even Franklin. I wonder what the first woman President's first name will be.

questions.correct: William Henry Harrison & William Harrison & William H. Harrison
questions.explanation:
William Henry Harrison & William Harrison & William H. Harrison

	1841, period. This is a sad story: poor guy died of longwindedness. After giving a 105-minute inaugural speech on a freezing March day (hatless), he contracted pneumonia and died! By the way, I left out poor James Garfield, 1881, who was shot by the deranged Charles Guiteau and later died of blood poisoning.
